Comment:
In this game, White challenged black (me) to a vigorous game of Chess. Unfortunately, it resulted in the systematic destruction of White's power.  Instead of crushing my opponent, I just picked White off before looking for opportunities to get a checkmate, while avoiding checkmate myself.  She had me at the ropes several times, but I managed to checkmate White in 26 moves. 

White opens with King Pawn opening (e4).
Black responds in kind. ...e5.

(?) Here White has moved to h3, which is a preventive move on White's part.  In my experience with playing this player, she moves her a and h pawns in order to prevent the bishops from pinning her knights.  I respond as Black by deploying my gN to f6.

(?) Here White has moved to h3, which is a preventive move on White's part.  In my experience with playing this player, she moves her a and h pawns in order to prevent the bishops from pinning her knights.  I respond as Black by deploying my gN to f6.
White could set up for the Lolli Attack if she set up correctly.  White could have moved KN to Nf3 at the beginning and gotten aggressive.  Here, a 3 knight defense manfests itself.
White could set up for the Lolli Attack if she set up correctly.  White could have moved KN to Nf3 at the beginning and gotten aggressive.  Here, a 3 knight defense manfests itself.
White deploys her Queen at this point.
White deploys her Queen at this point.
White deploys her Queen at this point.

Black promptly takes an outpost supported by e5, in order to challenge the Queen.  My target as Black was the undefended c2 pawn.  ...Nc2, Kd1, Nxa1. I had no interest in the Queen at that time, even though she would have been a tasty target if White moved Kd1.
White's queen retreats to d1, losing tempo, but a sensible defense at that.
Here, Black castled to make sure his King was safe.

White Castles at this move.  Notice how White is challenging my Knight.  I ignored that challenge since my Knight is on a superb outpost.  My opponent's queen is trapped by her own pieces after losing tempo.

Nxe4 because of the poor defense of e4's pawn. I am now challenging the knight on c3.
White should have taken Black's knight on e4 at this point.  White should have been on a great outpost.
White should have taken Black's knight on e4 at this point.  White should have been on a great outpost.

Black moves in to go Check to the King.  The queen is lost.

White's King moves to h2.
Black gobbles up White's Queen.
White's Rook finally eats Black's Knight.
Black takes control of the e file.
After White moves his Knight to c4, Black presses his pawn to d5 in order to take the center and to threaten White's Bishop on c4.
